content.raw:
`generate_objects` returns a generator where it seems like `make_data` is only ever called once. Can you show how it’s called more than once? An example?

As another aside, in the migration we should be really changing all uses of `__str__` to `__unicode__` \(and especially if that solves the issue\). The current call to `__str__` should wrap to a proper call to `__unicode__`.
content.html:
generate_objects returns a generator where it seems like make_data is only ever called once. Can you show how it’s called more than once? An example?

As another aside, in the migration we should be really changing all uses of __str__ to __unicode__ (and especially if that solves the issue). The current call to __str__ should wrap to a proper call to __unicode__.

content.raw:
How was `process_job` called so that 

    num_segs, num_frames, maxvmem, cpu, exit_status

all ended up being empty on those lines in the first place?

A diff would still be very helpful in clarifying any issues here.
content.html:
How was process_job called so that 

num_segs, num_frames, maxvmem, cpu, exit_status

all ended up being empty on those lines in the first place?

A diff would still be very helpful in clarifying any issues here.

content.raw: Sorry this was poorly expressed, each row represents a round of each job, once it has begun. The full line, with num\_seg, cpu, etc. is only written when the job is actually completed, and has no more rounds to do. As you can see, the job 1165846 is printed second because it runs an extra round.
content.html: Sorry this was poorly expressed, each row represents a round of each job, once it has begun. The full line, with num_seg, cpu, etc. is only written when the job is actually completed, and has no more rounds to do. As you can see, the job 1165846 is printed second because it runs an extra round.

content.raw: Could you show a precise before/after of what this code change does? The jobids above are also confusing since they should all be different. Also why did some jobs in the log having missing prog, num\_seg, num\_frames, maxvmem, cpu and exit status to begin with?
content.html: Could you show a precise before/after of what this code change does? The jobids above are also confusing since they should all be different. Also why did some jobs in the log having missing prog, num_seg, num_frames, maxvmem, cpu and exit status to begin with?

content.raw: Yes
content.html: Yes

content.raw: Was this issue ever reported to the GMTK maintainers?
content.html: Was this issue ever reported to the GMTK maintainers?

content.raw: Shouldn’t this be under the hoffmanlab group dockerhub area similar to Genomedata?
content.html: Shouldn’t this be under the hoffmanlab group dockerhub area similar to Genomedata?

content.raw: The latest version of Numpy no longer supports 3.3 or earlier, I thought it made the most sense to drop support for this then
content.html: The latest version of Numpy no longer supports 3.3 or earlier, I thought it made the most sense to drop support for this then

content.raw:
No this prints the log line after the jobs have finished. If viterbi runs an extra iteration it would be logged second, despite being called first. Printing after every iteration could get you a log file like this

jobid	jobname	prog	num\_segs	num\_frames	maxvmem	cpu	exit\_status  
1165846	vit0.identifydir-seg.959d9cbe748611e885bbbc305bf153a8	  
1165847	jt0.identifydir-seg.959d9cbe748611e885bbbc305bf153a8	  
1165846	vit0.identifydir-seg.959d9cbe748611e885bbbc305bf153a8	  
1165847	jt0.identifydir-seg.959d9cbe748611e885bbbc305bf153a8	

1165847	jt0.identifydir-seg.959d9cbe748611e885bbbc305bf153a8	gmtkJT	2	8000	1104023552.0000	2.2897	0  
1165846	vit0.identifydir-seg.959d9cbe748611e885bbbc305bf153a8	  
1165846	vit0.identifydir-seg.959d9cbe748611e885bbbc305bf153a8	gmtkViterbi	2	8000	1823936512.0000	2.0807	0

Because Viterbi ran an extra time, its full log line appears after. This behaviour was happening in both python 2 and 3, I was never able to figure out why it only started now though and not before the conversion began.
content.html:
No this prints the log line after the jobs have finished. If viterbi runs an extra iteration it would be logged second, despite being called first. Printing after every iteration could get you a log file like this

jobid jobname prog num_segs num_frames maxvmem cpu exit_status
1165846 vit0.identifydir-seg.959d9cbe748611e885bbbc305bf153a8
1165847 jt0.identifydir-seg.959d9cbe748611e885bbbc305bf153a8
1165846 vit0.identifydir-seg.959d9cbe748611e885bbbc305bf153a8
1165847 jt0.identifydir-seg.959d9cbe748611e885bbbc305bf153a8

1165847 jt0.identifydir-seg.959d9cbe748611e885bbbc305bf153a8 gmtkJT 2 8000 1104023552.0000 2.2897 0
1165846 vit0.identifydir-seg.959d9cbe748611e885bbbc305bf153a8
1165846 vit0.identifydir-seg.959d9cbe748611e885bbbc305bf153a8 gmtkViterbi 2 8000 1823936512.0000 2.0807 0

Because Viterbi ran an extra time, its full log line appears after. This behaviour was happening in both python 2 and 3, I was never able to figure out why it only started now though and not before the conversion began.

content.raw: But this *is* the order in which the jobs were called. Gathering and then sorting the jobs obscures this fact. How is this different from Python 2 behavior?
content.html: But this is the order in which the jobs were called. Gathering and then sorting the jobs obscures this fact. How is this different from Python 2 behavior?

content.raw: Originally, it had been rearranged to match their order of appearance in the touchstone files. I then noticed that their order was inconsistent in those files. I’ll change the arrangement back
content.html: Originally, it had been rearranged to match their order of appearance in the touchstone files. I then noticed that their order was inconsistent in those files. I’ll change the arrangement back

content.raw: Where does the `3.4` version specifically come from?
content.html: Where does the 3.4 version specifically come from?

content.raw: It's worthwhile to consider changing the frequent `list(map(func, somelist))` pattern to something like `[func(x) for x in somelist]`. This is largely a matter of preference and style and maybe @hoffman would have a preference in this case.
content.html: It's worthwhile to consider changing the frequent list(map(func, somelist)) pattern to something like [func(x) for x in somelist]. This is largely a matter of preference and style and maybe @hoffman would have a preference in this case.

content.raw: Why was this rearranged?
content.html: Why was this rearranged?

content.raw: Originally this function was called every time generate\_objects, which is used when generating a str. This meant that the values would change every time it was outputted. This caused a problem because the expression `'%s' % w` will call \_\_str\_ twice when w is unicode in python 2, as is the case here. This expression is called in the template.substitute method of str, used by us to print out all our param values. It seemed best to have a constructor store the data in a class variable that could be accessed any time, rather than only have it correct the first time.
content.html: Originally this function was called every time generate_objects, which is used when generating a str. This meant that the values would change every time it was outputted. This caused a problem because the expression '%s' % w will call __str_ twice when w is unicode in python 2, as is the case here. This expression is called in the template.substitute method of str, used by us to print out all our param values. It seemed best to have a constructor store the data in a class variable that could be accessed any time, rather than only have it correct the first time.

content.raw: Add a “ “ before “This”
content.html: Add a “ “ before “This”

content.raw: Why was this changed to a constructor?
content.html: Why was this changed to a constructor?

content.raw: These log lines are now printed together once every process has finished running in wait. This allows them to be sorted so they appear in the order the jobs were called. This happens in the wait function which calls this one
content.html: These log lines are now printed together once every process has finished running in wait. This allows them to be sorted so they appear in the order the jobs were called. This happens in the wait function which calls this one

content.raw: Why was this moved from above?
content.html: Why was this moved from above?

content.raw: Why was this removed?
content.html: Why was this removed?

content.raw: The byte\_string function immediately used after it's been partially applied. Why not just call `resource_string(PKG_DATA, resource).decode(SEGWAY_ENCODING)` directly?
content.html: The byte_string function immediately used after it's been partially applied. Why not just call resource_string(PKG_DATA, resource).decode(SEGWAY_ENCODING) directly?

content.raw: This should be reported as a bug to GMTK maintainers. In their configuration setup this should be a default flag for the compiler.
content.html: This should be reported as a bug to GMTK maintainers. In their configuration setup this should be a default flag for the compiler.

content.raw: The segway.bed.gz files were edited so the headers appear in alphabetical order; this change should not make a difference and the files can still be opened by the UCSC Genome Browser. This change allows for consistent output between Python 2 and Python 3. Because they’re zipped files, the changes will not appear in the pull request below.
content.html: The segway.bed.gz files were edited so the headers appear in alphabetical order; this change should not make a difference and the files can still be opened by the UCSC Genome Browser. This change allows for consistent output between Python 2 and Python 3. Because they’re zipped files, the changes will not appear in the pull request below.
